Comment_glosser: This form is a transformational error. Chan’s database says “ɪ /ʊpyn” but the variation only refers to the vowel, i.e., this form is actually not ɪ but ɪpyn.

There is another error here: the form should be ypyn based on Buddruss & Degener (2015: 480), i.e., where Chan’s data come from. Full source: Buddruss, Georg & Almuth Degener. 2015. Materialien zur Prasun-Sprache des afghanischen Hindukusch. Teil 1: Texte und Glossar. Cambridge, Mass.: Harvard University Press. In fact, the whole dataset either contains plenty of transcription errors (such as the use of ʐ instead of d͡z) or the data come from a different source than Buddruss & Degener (& Morgenstierne) after all.
Not transparent synchronically but probably not atomic either (at least historically)?
Theoretically 10′⋅20 but it is unclear what 10′ is and the form is missing entirely in Buddruss & Degener, the alleged source of this doculect.
Either atomic or analyzable as 4(′?)⋅100, in which case I would suspect it to be a loanword.
